title: Grant City, Staten Island
text:
Grant City is the name of a neighborhood located on the <a href="East%20Shore%2C%20Staten%20Island">East Shore</a> of <a href="Staten%20Island">Staten Island</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>.
To the east of Grant City lies <a href="Midland%20Beach%2C%20Staten%20Island">Midland Beach</a>, and a high cliff to the west of Richmond Road separates Grant City from <a href="Todt%20Hill">Todt Hill</a>. <a href="New%20Dorp%2C%20Staten%20Island">New Dorp</a> is situated immediately south of Grant City. <a href="Dongan%20Hills%2C%20Staten%20Island">Dongan Hills</a> is situated to the north.
History.
Originally known as Frenchtown, the community was renamed in honor of <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a> General <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a> soon after the conflict began, despite the fact that the war itself was so unpopular on Staten Island that the island was the scene of anti-<a href="Draft%20Riot%20of%201863">draft riot</a>s in July 1863. Many of the streets are named after historical figures such as Lincoln Ave (after President <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a>), Fremont Ave (after General <a href="John%20C.%20Fremont">John C. Fremont</a> who was the first Republican candidate for president, as well as a Staten Island resident, in 1856), Adams Avenue (after President <a href="John%20Adams">John Adams</a>), Colfax Ave (after Vice President <a href="Schuyler%20Colfax">Schuyler Colfax</a>) and Greeley Ave (after newspaper editor <a href="Horace%20Greeley">Horace Greeley</a>). Many other streets were originally named after historical figures but those streets have been renamed.
Many small, one-family homes were built in Grant City in the 1950s, with a stronger growth spurt occurring after the opening of the <a href="Verrazano-Narrows%20Bridge">Verrazano-Narrows Bridge</a> in November 1964 made access to the island from <a href="Brooklyn%2C%20New%20York">Brooklyn</a> much easier. Today the neighborhood's population is heavily <a href="Italian-American">Italian-American</a> by ethnicity and <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> by religion, and many of its residents were born in Brooklyn. Grant City and the neighborhoods surrounding it are also very <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> politically, with <a href="U.S.%20Republican%20Party">Republican Party</a> candidates for most elected offices.
Notable events.
In August 1990 an <a href="Fujita%20scale">F0</a> tornado made its way north along Fremont Ave. in Grant City, toppling 100-plus year old trees and causing widespread damage.
Transportation.
Grant City is served by the along Midland Avenue and Lincoln Avenue, the <a href="S74%20%28New%20York%20City%20bus%29">S74</a>, <a href="S76%20%28New%20York%20City%20bus%29">S76</a>, <a href="S84%20%28New%20York%20City%20bus%29">S84</a>, <a href="S86%20%28New%20York%20City%20bus%29">S86</a> and <a href="SIM15%20%28New%20York%20City%20bus%29">SIM15</a> along Richmond Road, and the along Hylan Blvd. It is also served by express buses along Hylan Boulevard.
The <a href="Grant%20City%20station">Grant City station</a> on the <a href="Staten%20Island%20Railway">Staten Island Railway</a> serves the community. The station immediately to the north is located at <a href="Jefferson%20Avenue%20station">Jefferson Avenue</a>, near the boundary between Grant City and neighboring <a href="Dongan%20Hills%2C%20Staten%20Island">Dongan Hills</a>.
